marklogic.body: Thanks for the explanation. Yes, I can see the limitation with the altimeter. It's just disappointing because, I would like to calibrate it before a hike (or a mountain climb) but if I Â have an accurate calibration and start climbing up to a certain altitude while tracking the changes using the log... how will I ever know if the tracking is accurate? Also to calibrate the altimeter, I need to put in the correct sea level pressure in the reference setting? Where as to calibrate the barometer, I need to put in the correct altitude? I thought just putting in either value would be ok. Hmm.. I use google earth to find the elevation at home and at work. I set the correct altitude for home and when I get to work the altitude for work doesn't match up... and vice versa. It's by anywhere from 60-100ft. Also, at work when I set a correct reference altitude outside the door, walk upstairs to my office... and come back down to the outside again during my break... the altitude is different from the one that I had previously set at the same Spot. Hmm... maybe that was the varing air pressure you refer to even in normal stable weather conditions. Â As for the GPS + barometer in watch thing... that would probably be more accurate... but probably also more expensive and Battery draining. At that point, I might consider just getting a Garmin eTrex GPS or something. I wonder how accurate those are?
